case_data.name: EEOC v. Golden Gate Meat Company, Inc.
case_data.plaintiff_description: Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, on behalf of one or more workers.
settlement_agreement: Court Approved Settlement or Consent Decree
case_data.summary: The EEOC district office of San Francisco filed this suit against Golden Gate Meat Company, Inc., in September 2003, in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California.  The compliant alleged disparate treatment based on national origin discrimination in violation of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.  In October 2004 the parties settled the case through mediation and a consent decree was issued.The consent decree stated that the defendant must (1) revise its current nondiscrimination policy to produce an environment free of retaliation and discrimination based on race, color, sex, national origin, or religion; (2) post notices of the new policy and deliver the new policies to current employees and new employees; (3) train all its employees, including management, on the issues concerning all types of employment discrimination; (4) keep records of all postings and training so the EEOC may inspect the records yearly; (5) and pay the aggrieved employees a total sum of $65,000 (division unknown).The decree was entered in 2004 and scheduled to last 2007. No further docket entries exist, so the case is presumably closed.

Case 3:03-cv-04313-MMC     Document 62     Filed 10/13/2004     Page 1 of 6
1 WILLIAM R. TAMAYO -- #084965 (CA)
JONATHAN T.  PECK -- #12303 (VA)
2 CINDY O'HARA -- #114555 (CA)
EVANGELINA HERNANDEZ – #168879 (CA)
3 EQUAL EMPLOYMENT OPPORTUNITY 
  COMMISSION
4 San Francisco District Office
350 The Embarcadero, Suite 500
5 San Francisco, California  94105
Telephone: (415) 625-5653
6 Facsimile: (415) 625-5657
7 Attorneys for Plaintiff Equal Employment Opportunity Commission
8
9 UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT
10 NORTHERN DISTRICT OF CALIFORNIA
11
12 EQUAL EMPLOYMENT OPPORTUNITY ) Civil Action No.   C-03-4313 MMC/JCS
COMMISSION, )
13 ) CONSENT DECREE BETWEEN
Plaintiff, ) EQUAL EMPLOYMENT
14 ) OPPORTUNITY COMMISSION AND
v. ) GOLDEN GATE MEAT COMPANY,
15 ) INC.
)
16 GOLDEN GATE MEAT COMPANY, INC. )
)
17 Defendant. )
_______________________________________ )
18
19 Plaintiff Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (“Commission”) filed this action
20 under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and Title I of the Civil Rights Act of 1991 to
21 correct alleged unlawful employment practices on the basis of discrimination  based on national
22 origin, and to provide appropriate relief to individuals who the Commission alleged were
23 adversely affected by such practices.  The Commission alleged that Defendant Golden Gate Meat
24 Company, Inc.  (“Golden Gate Meat”) subjected employees to unlawful harassment based on
25 their national origin in violation of Title VII.  Defendant Golden Gate Meat denied the
26 allegations and contends that its employees were treated fairly in accordance with the company’s
27 anti-discrimination policies.  The Commission and Defendant Golden Gate Meat now seek to
28 resolve this action as to each other and as between Golden Gate Meat and the Charging Party
Consent Decree Between Equal Employment Opportunity Commission and Golden Gate Meat Company, Inc. Page 1

Case 3:03-cv-04313-MMC     Document 62     Filed 10/13/2004     Page 2 of 6
1 without further contested litigation through the instant Consent Decree.  This resolution does not
2 constitute an admission of liability on the part of Golden Gate Meat, nor constitute a finding on
3 the allegations stated in the Commission’s Complaint.
4 The Court has reviewed this Consent Decree in light of the pleadings, the record herein,
5 and the applicable law, and now approves this Consent Decree.
6 THEREFORE IT IS HEREBY ORDERED, ADJUDGED AND DECREED:
7 GENERAL PROVISIONS
8 1. This Court has jurisdiction over the subject matter and the parties to this action for
9 purposes of this Consent Decree.  This Court retains jurisdiction over this Consent Decree during
10 its term.  At the end of its term, this Consent Decree will expire with the same force and effect as
11 if it had been dismissed with prejudice.
12 2. This Consent Decree constitutes a full and final resolution of the Commission’s
13 claims against Golden Gate Meat in this action.
14 3. This Consent Decree will become effective upon its entry by the Court.
15 4. This Consent Decree is final and binding upon the parties to it, their successors
16 and assigns.
17 5. The Commission and Golden Gate Meat will each bear its own costs and
18 attorneys fees in this action.
19 GENERAL INJUNCTIVE RELIEF
20 6. Golden Gate Meat and its current officers, agents, and employees will comply
21 with all requirements of Title VII with respect to providing a work environment free from
22 discrimination, including harassment, on the basis of national origin at the Golden Gate Meat
23 premises.
24 7. Golden Gate Meat and its current officers, agents, and employeesagree not to
25 retaliate against Charging Party Jose Elmer Carrasco and/or any current or former employees of
26 Golden Gate Meat for having testified or participated in any manner in the Commission’s
27 investigation and the proceedings in this case.   This paragraph expressly excludes any charges of
28 //
Consent Decree Between Equal Employment Opportunity Commission and Golden Gate Meat Company, Inc. Page 2

Case 3:03-cv-04313-MMC     Document 62     Filed 10/13/2004     Page 3 of 6
1 retaliation which have been filed with the EEOC prior to the date of entry of this Consent
2 Decree.
3 SPECIAL INJUNCTIVE RELIEF
4 Non-Discrimination Policies
5 8. Within sixty (60) days of the entry of this Decree, Golden Gate Meat will revise
6 its non-discrimination policy to address national origin-based discrimination and harassment,
7 including examples of such harassment and why such harassment is illegal.  The policy will
8 include a fair and effective discrimination complaint procedure.  Said revisions will be provided
9 to counsel for the Commission within one week of their printing.
10 9. Within sixty (60) days of the entry of this Consent Decree, Golden Gate Meat will
11 have translated the non-discrimination policies referenced in paragraph 8 above into Spanish.
12 10. Within ninety (90) days of the entry of this Consent Decree, Golden Gate Meat
13 will distribute the non-discrimination policies referenced in paragraph 8 above to all employees,
14 both management and non-management, and will obtain a dated and signed acknowledgment of
15 receipt from each employee.  No later than one week after the distribution of the non-
16 discrimination policies, Golden Gate Meat will contact counsel for the Commission and arrange a
17 meeting for the Commission to cross-check the acknowledgments of receipt with the employee
18 roster.  Said non-discrimination policies will be distributed to all new employees within one week
19 of their hire date; signed and dated acknowledgment of receipt forms will also be obtained from
20 these employees.  Once per year, on the anniversary date of the entry of this Consent Decree,
21 counsel for the Commission will contact counsel for Golden Gate Meat and arrange a meeting for
22 the Commission to cross-check all acknowledgments of receipt for any new employees with the
23 employee roster; the last year of the term of the Consent Decree, counsel for the Commission will
24 contact counsel for Golden Gate Meat one month prior to the expiration of the Decree, so that the
25 final review will be conducted prior to the expiration of the decree.    The Commission will return
26 originals and all copies of acknowledgment forms and rosters at the end of each meeting
27 referenced in this paragraph.
28 //
Consent Decree Between Equal Employment Opportunity Commission and Golden Gate Meat Company, Inc. Page 3

Case 3:03-cv-04313-MMC     Document 62     Filed 10/13/2004     Page 4 of 6
1 Training
2 11. No later than ninety (90) days from the entry of this Consent Decree, Golden Gate
3 Meat will use an outside consultant, paid for by Golden Gate Meat, to train all employees, both
4 management and non-management, regarding discrimination, including discrimination based on
5 national origin and discriminatory harassment.  Said training will be given in both English and in
6 Spanish.  This training will be repeated on a yearly basis each year for the duration of this
7 Consent Decree.
8 Record Keeping, Reports and Posting
9 12. Within thirty (30) days after completing the training described in paragraph 11,
10 Golden Gate Meat will contact counsel for the Commission to arrange a meeting where counsel
11 for the Commission will be provided with the date(s) of training, copies of all materials
12 distributed at the training, and a list of all attendees, which counsel for the Commission will be
13 able to cross-check against the employee roster.  For the convenience of counsel, this meeting
14 may be combined with the meeting referenced in paragraph 10 above.  The original and all copies
15 of materials reviewed by the Commission will be returned at the end of the meeting.
16 13. Once every three months, to be measured beginning at the date of entry of this
17 Consent Decree and continuing for the duration of this Consent Decree, Golden Gate Meat will
18 notify counsel for the Commission whether any of its employees have made any complaints of
19 discrimination and/or harassment based on national origin to any Golden Gate Meat managers,
20 what steps were taken in response to that information, and how the situation was resolved.
21 14. An agreed-upon Notice in English and Spanish concerning the provisions of this
22 Consent Decree and the right of employees to work in a workplace free of discrimination and
23 harassment based on national origin shall be posted in a clearly visible location frequented by
24 employees, on Golden Gate Meat’s worksite, during the term of this Decree, and shall remain
25 posted for the duration of this Consent Decree.  Defendant will monitor the posting and will
26 replace it if it is defaced or removed.
27 //
28 //
Consent Decree Between Equal Employment Opportunity Commission and Golden Gate Meat Company, Inc. Page 4

Case 3:03-cv-04313-MMC     Document 62     Filed 10/13/2004     Page 5 of 6
1 MONETARY RELIEF
2 15. Golden Gate Meat will pay the sum of $65,000.00, to be allocated among the
3 Charging Party and similarly situated employees as determined by the Equal Employment
4 Opportunity Commission, as damages and in complete satisfaction of the Commission’s claims
5 against Golden Gate Meat as set forth in its Complaint.  These money damages  will be paid on
6 the following payment schedule: (1) One third to be paid not later than January 31, 2005; (2) one
7 third to be paid not later than January 31, 2006; and (3) the remainder to be paid not later than
8 January 31, 2007.  These sums will be paid by check made out directly to each individual in his
9 name, and will be sent to Commission counsel Cindy O’Hara at the San Francisco District Office,
10 who will then forward the checks to the individual recipients.   The payment of any monies under
11 this Consent Decree is conditioned on the execution of a release between Golden Gate Meat and
12 recipient.  The Commission will collect the  releases from the Charging Party and from any other
13 party to be paid under the terms of this Consent Decree, and transmit each release to Golden Gate
14 Meat with a written request for payment.  Golden Gate Meat will transmit the checks no later
15 than January 31 of the year specified for payment above. Should any of these monies be
16 unclaimed sixty (60) days after the expiration of this decree, said monies will be given to the
17 Mexican American Legal Defense and Education Fund for the purpose of serving the needs of
18 Latino and/or immigrant workers.
19 EXPIRATION OF CONSENT DECREE
20 16. This Consent Decree constitutes a full and final resolution of all the Commission’s
21 claims against Golden Gate Meat in this action. This Consent Decree will expire three (3)  years
22 after its entry by the Court, provided that Golden Gate Meat has substantially complied with the
23 terms of this Consent Decree.  Golden Gate Meat will be deemed to have complied substantially

19 DefendantGolden Gate Meat Company, Inc. ("Golden Gate Meat")answers
20 plaintiffEqual Employment Opportunity Commission's ("Plaintiff") Complaint, brought on behalf 
21 of Jose Elmer Carrasco ("Charging Party") and "similarly situated Hispanic employees,"and
22 hereby admits, denies, alleges and avers as follows:
23 ANSWER TO ALLEGATION RE: NATURE OF THE ACTION
24 1. Answering the introductory paragraph of the Complaint, defendantGolden
25 Gate Meat admits that Plaintiff is bringing this action "pursuant to Title VII or [sic] the Civil 
26 Rights Act of 1964 and Title I of the Civil Rights Act of 1991," and that Plaintiff, by its 
27 Complaint, seeks relief for the Charging Party and similarly situated Hispanic employees.
28 DefendantGolden Gate Meat denies that it engaged in any unlawful employment practices on the 
-1-
W02-SF:FWJ\61391628.1 ANSWER TO COMPLAINT

Case 3:03-cv-04313-MMC     Document 4     Filed 12/19/2003     Page 2 of 9
1 basis of national origin. DefendantGolden Gate Meat further denies that the Charging Party and 
2 similarly situated Hispanic employees were subjected to any unlawful discriminatory harassment 
3 based on their national origin. Except as so expressly admitted or denied, defendant Golden Gate 
4 Meat is without sufficient knowledge or information to form a belief as to the truth of the 
5 allegations contained in said paragraph, and on that basis denies each and every allegation 
6 contained therein.
7 ANSWER TO ALLEGATIONS OF JURISDICTION AND VENUE
8 2. Answering Paragraph 1 of the Complaint, defendantGolden Gate Meat
9 admits that this Court has jurisdiction over matters brought pursuant to 28 U.S.C. §§451, 1331, 
10 1337, 1343 and 1345.  Defendant Golden Gate Meat denies that the Court has jurisdiction over 
11 this matter because there is no actionable wrong arising under the Title VII of the Civil Rights Act 
12 of 1964 or the Civil Rights Act of 1991.  Except as so expressly admitted or denied, defendant 
13 Golden Gate Meat is without sufficient knowledge or information to form a belief as to the truth of 
14 the allegations contained in said paragraph, and on that basis denies each and every allegation 
15 contained therein.
16 3. Answering Paragraph 2 of the Complaint, defendantGolden Gate Meat 
17 admits that it does business in the judicial district of the United States District Court for the 
18 Northern District of California.  Defendant Golden Gate Meat denies that it did engage, or is now 
19 engaging, in any of the unlawful employment practices alleged in Plaintiff's Complaint.  Except as 
20 so expressly admitted or denied, defendant Golden Gate Meat is without sufficient knowledge or 
21 information to form a belief as to the truth of the allegations contained in said paragraph, and on 
22 that basis denies each and every allegation contained therein.
23 ANSWER TO STATEMENT RE: "INTRADISTRICT ASSIGNMENT"
24 4. Answering Paragraph 3 of the Complaint, defendantGolden Gate Meat
25 admits that it does business in San Francisco County and that its principle place of business is in 
26 San Francisco County.  Defendant Golden Gate Meat denies that it did engage, or is now 
27 engaging, in any of the unlawful employment practices alleged in Plaintiff's Complaint.  Except as 
28 so expressly admitted or denied, defendant Golden Gate Meat is without sufficient knowledge or 
-2-
W02-SF:FWJ\61391628.1 ANSWER TO COMPLAINT

Case 3:03-cv-04313-MMC     Document 4     Filed 12/19/2003     Page 3 of 9
1 information to form a belief as to the truth of the allegations contained in said paragraph, and on 
2 that basis denies each and every allegation contained therein.
3 ANSWER TO ALLEGATIONS RE: THE PARTIES
4 5. Answering Paragraph 4 of the Complaint, defendantGolden Gate Meat
5 admits that the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission is an agency of the United States 
6 charged with the administration, interpretation and enforcement of Title VII.  Defendant Golden 
7 Gate Meat is unable to identify the statutory reference cited by Plaintiff in Paragraph 4 of the 
8 Complaint– i.e., "§ 706(f)(1) and (3) of Title VII, §2000-e(f)(1) and (3)" – and is thuswithout
9 sufficient knowledge or information to form a belief as to the truth of the allegations contained in 
10 said paragraph, and on that basis denies each and every allegation contained therein.
11 6. Answering Paragraph 5 of the Complaint, defendantGolden Gate Meat 
12 admits the allegations contained therein.
13 7. Answering Paragraph 6 of the Complaint, defendantGolden Gate Meat 
14 admitsthe allegations contained therein.
15 ANSWER TO PLAINTIFF'S "STATEMENT OF CLAIMS"
16 8. Answering Paragraph 7 of the Complaint, defendantGolden Gate Meat
17 admits that Jose Elmer Carrasco filed a charge with Plaintiff alleging violations of Title VII.
18 Except as expressly admitted herein, defendant Golden Gate Meat is without sufficient knowledge 
19 or information to form a belief as to the truth of the allegations contained in said paragraph, and on 
20 that basis denies each and every allegation contained therein.
21 9. Answering Paragraph 8 of the Complaint, defendant Golden Gate Meat 
22 denies the allegations contained therein.
23 10. Answering Paragraph 9 of the Complaint, defendant Golden Gate Meat 
24 denies the allegations contained therein.
25 11. Answering Paragraph 10 of the Complaint, defendant Golden Gate Meat 
26 denies the allegations contained therein.
27 12. Answering Paragraph 11 of the Complaint, defendant Golden Gate Meat 
28 denies the allegations contained therein.
-3-
W02-SF:FWJ\61391628.1 ANSWER TO COMPLAINT

Case 3:03-cv-04313-MMC     Document 4     Filed 12/19/2003     Page 4 of 9
1 ANSWER TO PRAYER FOR RELIEF
2 13. Answering Plaintiff's prayer for relief,defendant Golden Gate Meat denies 
3 each and every allegation in Plaintiff's Prayer for Relief, Paragraphs A through G, denies that 
4 Charging Party and similarly situated Hispanic employees have been damaged in the manner 
5 alleged or in any other manner or amount whatsoever, and further denies that Charging Party and 
6 similarly situated Hispanic employees are entitled to any relief whatsoever.
7 AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSES
8 FIRST AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSE
9 (Failure to State a Claim)
10 The Complaint, and each purported claim for relief alleged therein, fails to state 
11 facts sufficient to constitute a claim for relief against Golden Gate Meat.
12 SECOND AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSE
13 (Statute of Limitations)
14 The Complaint, and each purported claim for relief alleged therein, is barred in 
15 whole or in part by the applicable statutes of limitations.
16 THIRD AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSE
17 (Laches)
18 Plaintiff's Complaint, and each purported claim for relief alleged therein, is barred 
19 in whole or in part by the doctrine of laches. 
20 FOURTH AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSE
21 (Estoppel)
22 DefendantGolden Gate Meat is informed and believes, and based thereon alleges, 
23 thatCharging Party and similarly situated Hispanic employees are estopped by their own actions 
24 and conduct from asserting any claim for relief against defendant Golden Gate Meat.
25 FIFTH AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSE
26 (Waiver)
27 DefendantGolden Gate Meat is informed and believes, and based thereon alleges, 
28 thatCharging Party and similarly situated Hispanic employeeshaveengaged in conduct and 
-4-
W02-SF:FWJ\61391628.1 ANSWER TO COMPLAINT

Case 3:03-cv-04313-MMC     Document 4     Filed 12/19/2003     Page 5 of 9
1 activity sufficient to constitute a waiver of any right to assert the claims upon which they now seek
2 relief.
3 SIXTH AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSE
4 (Unclean Hands)
5 DefendantGolden Gate Meat is informed and believes, and based thereon alleges, 
6 that Plaintiff's Complaint, and claims for relief alleged therein, is barred by the doctrine of unclean 
7 hands.
8 SEVENTH AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSE
9 (Failure to Exhaust Administrative Remedies)
10 Plaintiff's Complaint is barred, in whole or in part, to the extent Charging Party and 
11 similarly situated Hispanic employees failed to exhaust their administrative remedies and/or 
12 comply with necessary statutory prerequisites to filing this suit.
13 EIGHTH AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSE
14 (Business Justification)
15 Plaintiff's Complaint, and each purported claim for relief alleged therein, is barred 
16 becauseGolden Gate Meat's conduct has been reasonable and is justified by legitimate business 
17 and economic considerations.
18 NINTH AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSE
19 (Reasonableness and Good Faith)
20 DefendantGolden Gate Meat acted reasonably and in good faith at all times 
21 material herein, based on all relevant facts and circumstances known by it at the time it so acted.
22 Accordingly,Charging Party and similarly situated Hispanic employeesare barred from any 
23 recovery in this action.
24 TENTH AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSE
25 (Failure to Mitigate)
26 Charging Party and similarly situated Hispanic employeeshave failed to mitigate 
27 their losses, if any, and as a result of such failure, Charging Party and similarly situated Hispanic 
28 employees' claims against Golden Gate Meat are reduced, excused and/or discharged.
-5-
W02-SF:FWJ\61391628.1 ANSWER TO COMPLAINT

Case 3:03-cv-04313-MMC     Document 4     Filed 12/19/2003     Page 6 of 9
1 ELEVENTH AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSE
2 (Conditions Precedent)
3 Golden Gate Meat is informed and believes and thereon alleges that any obligations 
4 on the part of Golden Gate Meat to Charging Party and similarly situated Hispanic employees are
5 subject to conditions precedent which have not occurred and accordingly, Golden Gate Meat is not 
6 obligated and is not liable in any way toCharging Party and similarly situated Hispanic 
7 employees.
8 TWELFTH AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSE
9 (Performance of Duties)
10 DefendantGolden Gate Meat has fully performed its statutory, contractual, and 
11 other duties to Charging Party and similarly situated Hispanic employees, and Charging Party and 
12 similarly situated Hispanic employeesare therefore estopped from asserting any claim for relief 
13 against Golden Gate Meat.
14 THIRTEENTH AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSE
15 (Lack of Knowledge)
16 Defendant Golden Gate Meat asserts that it had no knowledge of any alleged 
17 discrimination, harassment, retaliation, or other claims alleged by Plaintiff.
18 FOURTEENTH AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSE
19 (Failure to Take Advantage of Preventative or Corrective Opportunities)
20 Charging Party and similarly situated Hispanic employees unreasonably failed to 
21 take advantage of any preventative or corrective opportunities provided by defendant Golden Gate 
22 Meatto avoid the alleged harm, if any.
23 FIFTEENTH AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSE
24 (After-Acquired Evidence)
25 Plaintiff's Complaint is barred, in whole or in part, by the doctrine of after-acquired
26 evidence.
27
28
-6-
W02-SF:FWJ\61391628.1 ANSWER TO COMPLAINT

Case 3:03-cv-04313-MMC     Document 4     Filed 12/19/2003     Page 7 of 9
1 SIXTEENTH AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSE
2 (No Damages)
3 Charging Party and similarly situated Hispanic employeeshave not suffered any 
4 damages as a result of any actions taken by Golden Gate Meat or its agents, and Charging Party 
5 and similarly situated Hispanic employeesare thus barred from asserting any claim for relief 
6 against Golden Gate Meat.
7 SEVENTEENTH AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSE
8 (Unconstitutionality of Punitive Damages)
9 Plaintiff's prayer for punitive damages is unconstitutional because it violates the 
10 due process clause of the Fourteenth Amendment to the Constitution of the United States and/or 
11 Section 7 of Article I of the Constitution of the State of California.
12 EIGHTEENTH AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSE
13 (Unconstitutionality of Punitive Damages)
14 Plaintiff's prayer for punitive damages is unconstitutional because it violates the 
15 excessive fines clause of the Eighth Amendment to the Constitution of the United States and/or 
16 Section 17 of Article I of the Constitution of the State of California.
17 NINETEENTH AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSE
18 (Failure to State Facts for Punitive Damages)
19 The Complaint, and each and every purported claim for relief alleged therein, fails 
20 to state facts sufficient to sustain the imposition of punitive damages against Golden Gate Meat.
21 TWENTIETH AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSE
22 (Reservation of Right to Amend Answer)
23 DefendantGolden Gate Meat hereby gives notice that it intends to rely on such 
24 other and further affirmative defenses as may become available during discovery in this action and 
25 reserves the right to amend its answer to assert any such defenses.
26
27
28

3 1. ThatPlaintiff, Charging Party and similarly situated Hispanic employees
4 take nothing by their Complaint, and that the Complaint be dismissed with prejudice;
5 2. That Golden Gate Meat be awarded its attorneys' fees and costs of suit 
incurred herein; and
6
3. For such other and further relief as the Court may deem just and proper.

documents.text:
Case 3:03-cv-04313-MMC     Document 61     Filed 10/12/2004     Page 1 of 6
1 WILLIAM R. TAMAYO -- #084965 (CA)
JONATHAN T.  PECK -- #12303 (VA)
2 CINDY O'HARA -- #114555 (CA)
EVANGELINA HERNANDEZ – #168879 (CA)
3 EQUAL EMPLOYMENT OPPORTUNITY 
  COMMISSION
4 San Francisco District Office
350 The Embarcadero, Suite 500
5 San Francisco, California  94105
Telephone: (415) 625-5653
6 Facsimile: (415) 625-5657
7 Attorneys for Plaintiff Equal Employment Opportunity Commission
8
9 UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT
10 NORTHERN DISTRICT OF CALIFORNIA
11
12 EQUAL EMPLOYMENT OPPORTUNITY ) Civil Action No.   C-03-4313 MMC/JCS
COMMISSION, )
13 ) CONSENT DECREE BETWEEN
Plaintiff, ) EQUAL EMPLOYMENT
14 ) OPPORTUNITY COMMISSION AND
v. ) GOLDEN GATE MEAT COMPANY,
15 ) INC.
)
16 GOLDEN GATE MEAT COMPANY, INC. )
)
17 Defendant. )
_______________________________________ )
18
19 Plaintiff Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (“Commission”) filed this action
20 under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and Title I of the Civil Rights Act of 1991 to
21 correct alleged unlawful employment practices on the basis of discrimination  based on national
22 origin, and to provide appropriate relief to individuals who the Commission alleged were
23 adversely affected by such practices.  The Commission alleged that Defendant Golden Gate Meat
24 Company, Inc.  (“Golden Gate Meat”) subjected employees to unlawful harassment based on
25 their national origin in violation of Title VII.  Defendant Golden Gate Meat denied the
26 allegations and contends that its employees were treated fairly in accordance with the company’s
27 anti-discrimination policies.  The Commission and Defendant Golden Gate Meat now seek to
28 resolve this action as to each other and as between Golden Gate Meat and the Charging Party
Consent Decree Between Equal Employment Opportunity Commission and Golden Gate Meat Company, Inc. Page 1

Case 3:03-cv-04313-MMC     Document 61     Filed 10/12/2004     Page 2 of 6
1 without further contested litigation through the instant Consent Decree.  This resolution does not
2 constitute an admission of liability on the part of Golden Gate Meat, nor constitute a finding on
3 the allegations stated in the Commission’s Complaint.
4 The Court has reviewed this Consent Decree in light of the pleadings, the record herein,
5 and the applicable law, and now approves this Consent Decree.
6 THEREFORE IT IS HEREBY ORDERED, ADJUDGED AND DECREED:
7 GENERAL PROVISIONS
8 1. This Court has jurisdiction over the subject matter and the parties to this action for
9 purposes of this Consent Decree.  This Court retains jurisdiction over this Consent Decree during
10 its term.  At the end of its term, this Consent Decree will expire with the same force and effect as
11 if it had been dismissed with prejudice.
12 2. This Consent Decree constitutes a full and final resolution of the Commission’s
13 claims against Golden Gate Meat in this action.
14 3. This Consent Decree will become effective upon its entry by the Court.
15 4. This Consent Decree is final and binding upon the parties to it, their successors
16 and assigns.
17 5. The Commission and Golden Gate Meat will each bear its own costs and
18 attorneys fees in this action.
19 GENERAL INJUNCTIVE RELIEF
20 6. Golden Gate Meat and its current officers, agents, and employees will comply
21 with all requirements of Title VII with respect to providing a work environment free from
22 discrimination, including harassment, on the basis of national origin at the Golden Gate Meat
23 premises.
24 7. Golden Gate Meat and its current officers, agents, and employeesagree not to
25 retaliate against Charging Party Jose Elmer Carrasco and/or any current or former employees of
26 Golden Gate Meat for having testified or participated in any manner in the Commission’s
27 investigation and the proceedings in this case.   This paragraph expressly excludes any charges of
28 //
Consent Decree Between Equal Employment Opportunity Commission and Golden Gate Meat Company, Inc. Page 2

Case 3:03-cv-04313-MMC     Document 61     Filed 10/12/2004     Page 3 of 6
1 retaliation which have been filed with the EEOC prior to the date of entry of this Consent
2 Decree.
3 SPECIAL INJUNCTIVE RELIEF
4 Non-Discrimination Policies
5 8. Within sixty (60) days of the entry of this Decree, Golden Gate Meat will revise
6 its non-discrimination policy to address national origin-based discrimination and harassment,
7 including examples of such harassment and why such harassment is illegal.  The policy will
8 include a fair and effective discrimination complaint procedure.  Said revisions will be provided
9 to counsel for the Commission within one week of their printing.
10 9. Within sixty (60) days of the entry of this Consent Decree, Golden Gate Meat will
11 have translated the non-discrimination policies referenced in paragraph 8 above into Spanish.
12 10. Within ninety (90) days of the entry of this Consent Decree, Golden Gate Meat
13 will distribute the non-discrimination policies referenced in paragraph 8 above to all employees,
14 both management and non-management, and will obtain a dated and signed acknowledgment of
15 receipt from each employee.  No later than one week after the distribution of the non-
16 discrimination policies, Golden Gate Meat will contact counsel for the Commission and arrange a
17 meeting for the Commission to cross-check the acknowledgments of receipt with the employee
18 roster.  Said non-discrimination policies will be distributed to all new employees within one week
19 of their hire date; signed and dated acknowledgment of receipt forms will also be obtained from
20 these employees.  Once per year, on the anniversary date of the entry of this Consent Decree,
21 counsel for the Commission will contact counsel for Golden Gate Meat and arrange a meeting for
22 the Commission to cross-check all acknowledgments of receipt for any new employees with the
23 employee roster; the last year of the term of the Consent Decree, counsel for the Commission will
24 contact counsel for Golden Gate Meat one month prior to the expiration of the Decree, so that the
25 final review will be conducted prior to the expiration of the decree.    The Commission will return
26 originals and all copies of acknowledgment forms and rosters at the end of each meeting
27 referenced in this paragraph.
28 //
Consent Decree Between Equal Employment Opportunity Commission and Golden Gate Meat Company, Inc. Page 3

Case 3:03-cv-04313-MMC     Document 61     Filed 10/12/2004     Page 4 of 6
1 Training
2 11. No later than ninety (90) days from the entry of this Consent Decree, Golden Gate
3 Meat will use an outside consultant, paid for by Golden Gate Meat, to train all employees, both
4 management and non-management, regarding discrimination, including discrimination based on
5 national origin and discriminatory harassment.  Said training will be given in both English and in
6 Spanish.  This training will be repeated on a yearly basis each year for the duration of this
7 Consent Decree.
8 Record Keeping, Reports and Posting
9 12. Within thirty (30) days after completing the training described in paragraph 11,
10 Golden Gate Meat will contact counsel for the Commission to arrange a meeting where counsel
11 for the Commission will be provided with the date(s) of training, copies of all materials
12 distributed at the training, and a list of all attendees, which counsel for the Commission will be
13 able to cross-check against the employee roster.  For the convenience of counsel, this meeting
14 may be combined with the meeting referenced in paragraph 10 above.  The original and all copies
15 of materials reviewed by the Commission will be returned at the end of the meeting.
16 13. Once every three months, to be measured beginning at the date of entry of this
17 Consent Decree and continuing for the duration of this Consent Decree, Golden Gate Meat will
18 notify counsel for the Commission whether any of its employees have made any complaints of
19 discrimination and/or harassment based on national origin to any Golden Gate Meat managers,
20 what steps were taken in response to that information, and how the situation was resolved.
21 14. An agreed-upon Notice in English and Spanish concerning the provisions of this
22 Consent Decree and the right of employees to work in a workplace free of discrimination and
23 harassment based on national origin shall be posted in a clearly visible location frequented by
24 employees, on Golden Gate Meat’s worksite, during the term of this Decree, and shall remain
25 posted for the duration of this Consent Decree.  Defendant will monitor the posting and will
26 replace it if it is defaced or removed.
27 //
28 //
Consent Decree Between Equal Employment Opportunity Commission and Golden Gate Meat Company, Inc. Page 4

Case 3:03-cv-04313-MMC     Document 61     Filed 10/12/2004     Page 5 of 6
1 MONETARY RELIEF
2 15. Golden Gate Meat will pay the sum of $65,000.00, to be allocated among the
3 Charging Party and similarly situated employees as determined by the Equal Employment
4 Opportunity Commission, as damages and in complete satisfaction of the Commission’s claims
5 against Golden Gate Meat as set forth in its Complaint.  These money damages  will be paid on
6 the following payment schedule: (1) One third to be paid not later than January 31, 2005; (2) one
7 third to be paid not later than January 31, 2006; and (3) the remainder to be paid not later than
8 January 31, 2007.  These sums will be paid by check made out directly to each individual in his
9 name, and will be sent to Commission counsel Cindy O’Hara at the San Francisco District Office,
10 who will then forward the checks to the individual recipients.   The payment of any monies under
11 this Consent Decree is conditioned on the execution of a release between Golden Gate Meat and
12 recipient.  The Commission will collect the  releases from the Charging Party and from any other
13 party to be paid under the terms of this Consent Decree, and transmit each release to Golden Gate
14 Meat with a written request for payment.  Golden Gate Meat will transmit the checks no later
15 than January 31 of the year specified for payment above. Should any of these monies be
16 unclaimed sixty (60) days after the expiration of this decree, said monies will be given to the
17 Mexican American Legal Defense and Education Fund for the purpose of serving the needs of
18 Latino and/or immigrant workers.
19 EXPIRATION OF CONSENT DECREE
20 16. This Consent Decree constitutes a full and final resolution of all the Commission’s
21 claims against Golden Gate Meat in this action. This Consent Decree will expire three (3)  years
22 after its entry by the Court, provided that Golden Gate Meat has substantially complied with the
23 terms of this Consent Decree.  Golden Gate Meat will be deemed to have complied substantially
24 //
25 //
26 //
27 //
28 //
Consent Decree Between Equal Employment Opportunity Commission and Golden Gate Meat Company, Inc. Page 5

Case 3:03-cv-04313-MMC     Document 61     Filed 10/12/2004     Page 6 of 6
1 if the Court has not made any findings or orders during the term of the Decree that Golden Gate
2 Meat has failed to comply with any of the terms of this Decree.
3
4 On Behalf of Plaintiff Commission: On Behalf of Defendant Golden Gate Meat:
5
